Summary of amendments/ Record documents superseded by:

data.text: INDEX
Purpose
From late 2017 all infants receive hepatitis B immunisation as part of the routine childhood programme at 8,  and 16 weeks.
This guideline relates to Post-exposure immunisations of infants born to Hepatitis B infected mothers.
To ensure that the infants of women identified during pregnancy of being at risk of receiving who are at risk of transmitting the Hepatitis B virus receive vaccination.
The appropriate immunisation schedule should be included on the mother hepatitis B booking results, and a plan of action written in the mothers notes.
To ensure that all infants requiring immunisation have it as soon as possible after birth and no later than 24 hours and before discharge home.
Equality and Diversity
Mid Essex Hospital services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix E)
High Risk Infants
(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Hepatitis B in Pregnancy and the Postnatal Period'; register number 12004)
The infants of women classified as high risk requiring vaccine and immunoglobulin: Refer (Appendix A)
Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) positive and hepatitis B e antigen positive;
HBsAg positive and Hep B e antigen negative and hepatitis B e antibody negative;
Mother is HBsAg positive where e-markers have not been determined;
Mothers had acute hepatitis B infection during pregnancy;
Mother is HBsAg seropositive and infant is born weighing 1500g or less;
A woman who is HBsAg seropositive and known to have an HBV DNA level equal or above 1x10 IUs/ml in an antenatal sample.
A neonatal alert form should be completed in the antenatal period and sent to the
Antenatal and Newborn Screening Co-ordinator located in the Screening Office,
Antenatal Clinic who will photocopy the alert form for her records. She will forward the
alert form to the named consultant paediatrician for a plan of care post delivery. Once a plan of care has been made a copy of the alert form will be filed in the Alert folder on NNU.
(Refer to Appendix B)
The neonatal alert form should have a copy of the patient's blood results and a neonatal prescription chart attached to enable the antenatal prescription to be completed.
All high risk infants need passive immunisation using anti-hepatitis immunoglobulin within 24 hours of birth as well as the hepatitis B vaccine.
At maternal diagnosis the immunoglobulin should be ordered from pharmacy and it should have been supplied by the woman's due date and available on the Neonatal Unit.
Dose: 200 units of hepatitis B immunoglobulin is given intramuscularly (IM) as well as Hepatitis B vaccine (Engerix)  microgram IM.
If giving both immunoglobulin and vaccine they should be given at the same time but in different legs.
Low Risk infants
Infants of mothers who are HBsAg positive and hepatitis B e antibody positive do not require immunoglobulin just vaccination (Engerix).
Procedure for Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin/vaccination
Obtain consent from the parents using the unscheduled immunisation consent form. (Refer to Appendix C)
Vaccine is a stock item and should be available at all times on the Postnatal Ward, the Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin (HBIG) is kept on the Neonatal Unit.

Neonatal hepatitis B vaccine and immunoglobulin is to be administered by the paediatric SHO/Registrar/Advanced Neonatal Nurse Practitioner (ANNP) as soon as possible after birth (vaccine within 24 hours).
Vaccine and immunoglobulin should be prescribed on the children's prescription chart.

The healthcare professional should decontaminate their hands and wear an apron and gloves. (Refer to the Trust guideline for ‘Prevention and management of latex allergy in health care workers; register number 04089)
Record in infant's “Personal Child Health Record” (Red Book), in the relevant page. (Refer to Appendix D)
Appropriate copy should be sent to Child health, with other relevant copy filed in the mother's notes.
The infants GP should be informed by letter that vaccine has been given as well as child health to ensure that further doses are given.
Follow-up
Infants require further doses at 1 months (2, 3 and 4 months as part of the routine childhood immunization) and 12 months.
Child health, once they receive notification of the hepatitis vaccination, will automatically send out the appointments for all other vaccination dates.
Staffing and Training
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes maternal antenatal screening tests.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Professional Midwifery Advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.

All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention. All invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using High Impact Intervention guidelines to reduce the risk of infection and deliver safe care. This care should be recorded in the Saving Lives High Impact Intervention Monitoring Tool Paperwork (Medical Devices).
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.
As a minimum the following specific requirements will be monitored:
4 sets of health records of patients who have delivered and who had screen positive test results for Hepatitis B.
A review of a suitable sample of health records of patients to include the minimum
requirements as highlighted in point 10.2 will be audited. A minimum compliance 75% is required for each requirement. Where concerns are identified more frequent audit will be undertaken.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Clinical Governance Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued and available to all staff including an update on the latest ‘guidelines' information such as a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Focus Magazine that is sent via email to all staff.
References
Department of Health: Immunisation against infectious disease (the Green Book); Chapter 18 v3_0 (June 2017)
Public Health England: Hepatitis B: guidance, data and analysis. The characteristics, diagnosis, management and epidemiology of hepatitis B. (Last updated 12 February 2019

British Viral Hepatitis Group. UK Guidelines for initial management of Hepatitis B Infection (2008) BVHG Consenus Statement : UK guidelines for the management of babies born to women who are HBsAg Positive.
Appendix A
Vaccination of babies according to the Hepatitis status of the Mother

table_items.text: Mother is HBsAg positive and HBeAg positive
Mother is HBsAg positive, HBeAg negative and antiHBe negative
Mother has acute hepatitis during pregnancy
Mother is HBsAg and antiHBe positive
Mother is HBsAg positive and known to have an HBV DNA level equal or above 1X106IUs/ml in any antenatal sample during this pregnancy (regardless og HBsAG anti anti-HBe status)
Mother is HBsAg positive and baby weighs 1500g or less

Neonatal Alert Form Criteria
Please use the neonatal alert form for the following conditions:
Multiple pregnancy (higher order > 2 fetus)    Severe oligohydramnios / IUGR
Hepatitis B positive mother    Abnormal dopplers
HIV positive mother    Genetic / hereditary conditions in the
Previous baby with GBBS sepsis / meningitis  immediate family that may affect the fetus
Significant structural abnormalities    Social e.g. drug abuse, alcohol abuse in this diagnosedon ultrasound scan  pregnancy
All cases that require referral to specialist    Any other condition that will require paediatric units for treatment or advice  input at birth
Mothers with high antibody titres e.g. Anti-D, C and Kell
Postnatal Plan (paediatric)
